scenario:
Broadcom (AVGO) has jumped 115% in the past year, while Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) has lost 14% of its value. Both companies design chips used in PCs, smartphones, gaming consoles, and data centers. AMD's third-quarter 2024 results show a turnaround in progress with an 18% year-over-year increase in revenue to $6.8 billion and a 31% spike in earnings per share to $0.92. Analysts project AMD's earnings to increase by 41% to $1.09 per share in the fourth quarter.

AMD's forecast for 2025 is rosier, with a 54% jump in earnings to $5.13 per share on the back of a 27% spike in revenue to $32.5 billion. The company's data center business gained momentum in 2024, and it is expected to witness further growth in 2025 due to an improved supply chain. AMD's share of the client CPU market increased by 4.6 percentage points year over year in the third quarter of 2024 to 23.9%.

Broadcom generated $12.2 billion in revenue last fiscal year from sales of its custom AI processors and networking chips, a massive jump of 220% from the preceding year. The company sees its addressable market in the AI space increasing to $60 billion to $90 billion by fiscal 2027. Broadcom controls 55% to 60% of the custom processor market and is expected to make the most of this lucrative growth opportunity.

Broadcom's AI revenue could jump to $45 billion after three years, a big jump of almost four times over the revenue generated in fiscal 2024. The company's non-AI semiconductor revenue fell 23% year over year in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2024, but it is expected to recover in the future. Broadcom's growth in fiscal 2025 is expected to be stronger than last year, with a 9% organic revenue growth.

Both AMD and Broadcom are likely to deliver robust growth in 2025 and beyond, but Broadcom is trading at a richer valuation than AMD. AMD is expected to deliver faster growth in the new year, making it a more attractive option for investors looking for a growth stock trading at an attractive valuation.
